abstract.p: This article attempts to (a) understand the quarterly seasonal behaviour of Net Asset Value of Equity Linked Savings Schemes (ELSS—Tax Saver Schemes), (b) analyse statistical significance of quarterly seasonal behaviour, (c) investigate the existence of unit root (Stationarity and Non-Stationarity time series of deseasonalised NAV) and (d) examine the weak form of efficient market hypothesis. Twenty tax saver schemes launched on or prior to 2006 were selected for analysis. The quarterly NAV data for the study period between 2006 and 2011 were obtained from respective asset management companies. The study reveals that (i) majority of the selected funds follow normal distribution, that is, seasonalised NAV is not skewed, (ii) 3rd quarter and 4th quarter of a calendar year are seen as appropriate for structuring investment decisions, (iii) statistical significance exists among the seasonal indices across quarters, (iv) autocorrelation function among the selected schemes are statistically significant, that is, deseasonalised NAV is non-stationary, (v) majority of schemes contains unit root at base level, that is, deseasonalised NAV is non-stationary, (vi) all schemes do not contain unit root at first differences, that is, deseasonalised NAV is stationary, (vii) deseasonalised NAV is weak–form inefficient, that is, cautious investors can have greater mileage by exploiting historical NAV and at the same time historical NAV facilitates to forecast future NAV on account of its non-randomness. Hence, this study accentuates that mutual fund investments are beneficial in the long run.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Mutual funds are pools of investors’ money. They invest in various ways specified in offer document and issue units to investors entitling them to a pro rata portion of the income generated by the funds (Bodie, Kane, Marcus and Mohanty, 2006). Despite the involvement of professional management, investor retains control over the broad features of the overall portfolio through the asset allocation decision and precisely all asset management companies offering such features in schemes to cater the requirements of every individual investor. The unit holders of mutual fund schemes hope that the fund managers can achieve superior investment performance than they could obtain on their own.

In today’s volatile market environment, mutual funds are looked upon as a transparent and low cost investment vehicle, which attracts a fair share of investor attention helping spur the growth of the industry. Albeit the fund managers exhibit timing the market as well as security selection, the performance of the fund is influenced by various factors such as (a) fund specific variables namely fund size, expenses ratio, portfolio turnover, load structure and so on (b) market specific variables namely inflation, interest rate, growth rate and market fluctuations and (c) managerial abilities of the fund managers namely qualification, experience, risk appetite, age and so on. In addition, Net Asset Value (NAV) of some specific category schemes have seen high momentum in a calendar year on account of increased demand for those schemes.

From investors’ perspective, though their investments are professionally managed, it is essential to analyse and understand the performance of mutual funds and this would apparently facilitate the investor to restructure their investment decision. Hence, performance analysis and determinants of mutual fund performance are the most sought research areas in Mutual Fund industry. Many research studies have revealed that cautiously structured portfolios, which cater to the requirement of investors, did not produce abnormal returns over a period of time as compared to a benchmark index and, such findings advocated the presence of efficient markets (Sharpe, 1966). In contrast, some research studies statistically signify that funds with higher aggressive objectives were outperformed the market by appropriately identifying securities, which were incorrectly priced (Carlson & Robert, 1970). On the other hand (Treynor, 1965), studies proved that in an efficient market, no security would be incorrectly priced. Theoretically, Efficient Market Hypothesis (EMH) states that security prices entirely reflect all available information and, prices will immediately adjust by itself as soon as any new information is disseminated in the market (Adam, 2004).

sec.title: Literature Review
sec.p: Seasonality and Market efficiency of Indian capital markets as well as international capital markets (specifically markets and corporate stocks) were well researched over a period of time in terms of their various forms, that is, Strong form, Semi-strong form and Weak form. The research studies reveal mixed evidences for domestic as well as in international capital markets exhibiting randomness and non-randomness. But there are only few research studies administrating the NAV of mutual fund units to understand their seasonality and randomness.

Khan, Ikram and Mehtab (2011) tested the market efficiency of Indian Capital Market in its weak form based on the indices of two major stock exchanges of India viz; National Stock Exchange (NSE) and Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE). The efficiency of the Indian capital market was tested using the daily closing values of the indices of NSE and BSE spanning 2000 to 2010. The research proved that Indian Capital market did not follow random walk model.

Chen, Estes and Ngo (2011) examined municipal bond returns, bond fund flows and buying activities by fund managers over the period 1990–2009. They found evidence of tax calendar-related rational opportunistic trading patterns by fund investors and fund managers. Specifically, fund shareholders conduct tax-loss selling in December and re-invest in January. In April, June and September, fund investors rationally cherry pick to sell their shares of short-term bond funds instead of their shares of long-term bond funds to raise cash to pay estimated taxes. Unlike fund shareholders, fund managers adopt a contrarian strategy of buying in December and selling in January.

Misra and Misra (2010) used a two-regime threshold autoregressive (TAR) model with an autoregressive unit root to examine the efficiency of the Indian stock market. They used 11 years weekly data for two indices and 10 common stocks from the National Stock Exchange (NSE) of India. The main finding of this study was that Indian stock prices follow a random walk albeit the presence of nonlinearities in the data.

Muhammad and Rahman (2010) studied whether (a) the return on common stock usually distributed as finance theory assumes, (b) volatility of stock returns changed over time (c) current distribution of returns affected by past returns. They found day of the week effect exists in Malaysian Exchange but only for the Monday effect.

Mishra (2009b) examined the informational efficiency of Indian capital market with specific reference to Mumbai Stock Exchange for a period of 18 years between 1991 and 2009 using Random Walk and GARCH model to find the weak form of efficiency and his study revealed weak form of inefficiency. Mishra (2009a) employed Unit Root tests on selected daily stock returns and presented evidence of weak form of inefficiency in India. He had also examined the mean reversion implication of market inefficiency and found the existence of mean reversion illusion in India.

Irala (2007) studied the significance of Beta value as a measure of market risk in Indian Stock market by using 660 companies’ monthly returns spanning 12 years. The study basically concentrated on stationarity of Beta in the Indian security markets and the Betas have a regression tendency to move towards the average Beta of 1.

Gupta and Basu (2007) tested the weak form efficiency in the framework of random walk hypothesis for the two major equity markets in India for the period 1991 to 2006. The evidence suggests that the series do not follow random walk model and there is an evidence of autocorrelation in both markets rejecting the weak form efficiency hypothesis.

Roy and Deb (2004) studied whether the Indian mutual fund managers contribute to better fund performance. They have used the lagged information variables such as Interest rate, dividend yield, term structure and April effect. The study revealed that conditional measures of past performance predict the future fund returns significantly and the time varying conditional alpha is found to be a better measure indicating persistence in performance of Indian mutual funds.

Choudhry (1994) examined the stochastic trends of individual stock indices in seven organisations of Economic Cooperation and development Countries (1953–1989) using Augmented Dickey-Fuller Unit root test and Johansen’s cointegration test. The research revealed that the stock markets are efficient during the sample period. Over a period of time, studies carried out to understand either the seasonality of securities or testing the efficient market hypothesis for indices but rarely observed studies on enumerating the seasonality of NAV or testing the weak form of efficiency of NAV.

Hence, this research study is carried out to accentuate the significance of quarterly seasonality and analysing whether the mutual fund units are correctly priced through efficient market hypothesis model.

sec.title: Objective, Data and Methodological Framework
sec.p: The primary purpose of this article is to investigate the presence of seasonal returns on a quarterly basis of select Equity Linked Savings Schemes (ELSS) operating in India during the period—2006 to 2011 (6 years). The Net Asset Values (NAV) of the schemes were obtained from the respective asset management companies. In order to precisely estimate seasonal behaviour of NAVs, all funds which were launched prior to 2006 were selected for the study. The collected data have been bifurcated into four distinctive quarters for every year (Calendar year) with January–March being treated as the first quarter. sec.title: Deseasonalisation Methodology: Ratio-to-Trend Method
sec.p: We primarily assume that the seasonal fluctuation in Net Asset Value of each quarter is a constant factor of the trend. As per the method, the quarterly NAVs have been consolidated into yearly NAV and Ordinary least square method has been applied to understand the average NAV and yearly incremental value (Beta of straight line equation) and estimate the yearly trend values.
Ŷ = Trend values of NAV
a = Average NAV
β = Yearly incremental/decremental value

Since, the calculated incremental value is on a yearly basis, they have been converted into quarterly incremental value by taking two middle quarters, that is 2nd quarter and 3rd quarter. In order to eliminate the trend in a multiplicative model, the quarterly time series NAV is divided by calculated quarterly trend NAV, which contains seasonal (S), cyclic (C) and irregular variations (I).

In order to eliminate the Cyclic and Irregular variation from SCI, these values are arranged season wise (Quarter) for the sample period by simple averages method. The deseasonalised NAVs are obtained through dividing the quarterly seasonalised NAV by seasonal index.

sec.title: Autocorrelation Function (ACF): Understanding the Disturbances from Lagged Deseasonalised NAV
sec.p: It is more prudent that any policy level changes with respect to the schemes or any generic market information perhaps tend to have impact in current Net Asset Value but there is no reason to believe that this information will be carried over to future Net Asset Value. If such evidence is found then, we said to have problem of autocorrelation and we can regard that the time series under consideration are non-stationary and symbolically we can present this as,(5)E (DNAVi DNAVj) ≠ i ≠ j

Correlation between two time series such as DNAV1, DNAV2, DNAV3….DNAV10 and DNAV2, DNAV3, DNAV4….DNAV11, where the former is the latter series lagged by one time period. After estimating the autocorrelation coefficient, the question arises that the computed autocorrelation coefficients at certain lag length exhibits statistical significance or not. Thus to understand the statistical significance, Box-Ljung statistic is used and following are the algorithm.

sec.title: Unit Root Test: Augmented Dickey—Fuller Test (ADF)
sec.p: In order to perform the Unit root test, we have considered the NAVt is a random walk with constant (technically known as drift) around a stochastic trend rather considering only random walk or random with constant. This can be symbolically presented as,(7)Δ DNAVt = β1 + β2 t + δDNAVt–1 + ut

Where,‘t’ is trend variable and ‘u’ is the white noise (residual). In this case the null hypothesis is δ = 0, that is, Deseasonalised NAV has unit root (DNAV) and the time series is non stationary. And the alternate hypothesis is that δ is less than zero; that is, the time series is stationary. Moreover, the above model presumes that the white noise (ut) is uncorrelated but if it is correlated, then the above model can be written as (Developed by Dicky-Fuller)(8)ΔDNAVt=β1+β2t+δDNAVt−1+ai∑i = 1mΔDNAVt−i+εt
Where, εt is a pure white noise term and ΔDNAVt–1 = DNAVt–1 – DNAVt–2, ΔDNAVt–2 = DNAVt–2 – DNAVt–3.The ADF statistic will also test whether δ = 0 against the alternate hypothesis that δ < 0.

sec.title: Research Findings
sec.p: Table 3 exhibits the descriptive statistics such as average NAV, Standard deviation, Co-efficient of variation, Skewness (Asymmetrical distribution), Kurtosis (Peakedness) and Normality test statistics. By considering the average NAV meaningful interpretation cannot be derived on account of variation in the period of inception, that is, schemes have longer time horizon in the market perhaps book higher NAV. Since, standard deviation is an absolute measure, co-efficient of variation will be more appropriate for understanding the risk related attributes pertaining to schemes under study. Among the 20 schemes, Taurus Tax Shield, Fidelity Tax Advantage Fund and Sahara Tax gain Fund have greater co-efficient variation, which explicitly indicates that these schemes are highly volatile schemes but earns higher returns and this is very apparent from Table 1 (CAGR: Taurus Tax Shield-8.09%, Fidelity Tax Advantage Fund-9.38%, Sahara Tax Gain-7.45%). LIC Nomura Tax Plan and Baroda Pioneer ELSS’96 have booked lesser co-efficient of variation compared all selected schemes. Skewness is a measure to understand whether the given data follows symmetrical distribution or asymmetrical distribution and lays foundation to validate that the data under study follows normal distribution. All selected schemes are exhibiting either positive or negative skewness. Based on Kurtosis none of the schemes exhibited meso-kurtic (β2=3), but either they are platy-kurtic (β2<3) or lepto-kurtic (β2>3). Generally, if skewness is zero and kurtosis is equal to three, then the sample follows normal distribution. In order to test the normality, we have applied Shapiro-Wilk normality test with assumption that Quarterly NAV follows normal distribution with various significance level (H0: Skewness=0). The result reveals that there is no possibility to reject the null hypothesis of all funds, which accentuates the quarterly NAV, follows normal distribution except Birla Tax Plan, BNP Paribas Tax Advantage Fund, Franklin India Tax Shield, Principal Tax saver funs, Sahara Tax Gain and Taurus Tax Shield. Among the afore mentioned schemes, Birla Tax Plan, Principal Tax saver funs, Sahara Tax Gain and Taurus Tax Shield rejects the null hypothesis at 0.05 significance level and BNP Paribas Tax Advantage Fund, Franklin India Tax Shield rejects the null hypothesis at 0.1 significance level, iterating that the quarterly NAVs does not follow normal distribution.

sec.p: Table 4 exhibits the Quarterly Seasonal Index component of respective schemes. The primary objective of determining the Seasonal index is to deseasonalise the quarterly NAV so that the treated data can be further used for statistical inferences. Secondly, it facilitates the Asset Management Company (Fund Managers) to season their mutual fund offerings and finally it provokes the individual investors to channelise their investments on account of fund manager’s best performance in the respective seasons as well. The research reveals that the 3rd Quarter and the 4th Quarter are the most seasoned quarters for Tax saver funds because regardless of category of investors such as Salaried, Self-employed, High Net-worth individuals or Institutional investors, they articulate their investment planning in those quarters led to immense appreciation in NAV. Other way, in order to attract existing as well as new investors, the fund managers would have exhibited their superior market timing and stock selection skills led to appreciation in NAV in the said quarters. It is also very apparent that any AMC proposes to float a Tax saver fund for public subscription; the market would have witnessed that New Fund Offers (NFO) either in 3rd quarter or 4th quarter. Thus, the 1st quarter or 2nd quarter of a calendar year would be more appropriate time for investing in Tax saver Funds and exit in 3rd quarter or 4th quarter to gain advantage after the minimum lock-in period.

sec.p: Table 5 shows the hypothesis test for homogeneity of mean Seasonal Indices. The null hypothesis accentuates that there is no significant difference among the quarterly Seasonal Indices of various quarters (H0: μ1= μ 2= μ3= μ4) against the alternate hypothesis that there is a significant difference exists among the quarterly seasonal indices (H1: μ1 μ2 μ3 μ4). The research reveals that the null hypothesis is rejected at 1 per cent level of significance and concluded that the quarterly seasonal indices are not equal for study period.

sec.p: Figure 1 lays strong foundation before application of any quantitative techniques to investigate the stationary and non-stationary of data. This graphical representation gives an initial clue about the likely nature of time series. From the plot, one can apparently view that the deseasonalised NAV has been exhibiting upward trend over a period of time, iterating that the deseasonalised NAV is changing, perhaps suggesting that the deseasonalised NAV is non-stationary. This is the initial grounding for applying formal tests for Stationarity.

caption.title: Graphical Analysis for Stationary and Non-stationary of NAV
caption.p: Source: Raw NAV data of selected schemes from respective AMCs between 2006 and 2011.

sec.p: Table 6 reveals correlation between the current quarter deseasonalised NAV and lagged quarter deseasonalised NAV. When autocorrelation coefficient is computed, we confronted with the following two questions.

(a) What should be the appropriate lag size? (b) At a particular lag, how to conclude whether the autocorrelation coefficient is statistically significant? The empirical rule of thump portrays that from the length of time series, one-third to one-fourth can be considered as appropriate lag size, hence grounded to maximum of 8 lags. In order to arrive at a statistical significance, Box-Ljung statistic is used at various alpha levels such as 0.01, 0.05 and 0.1. The correlogram exhibited in Figure 2 clearly indicates deseasonalised NAV is random. Thus, the deseasonalised NAV is non-stationary. The quantified autocorrelation values from Table 6 exhibits gradual decline when lag size increases. At lag 1, all funds exhibit high degree of positive autocorrelation except few schemes. At all lag sizes for all schemes, Box-Ljung statistic proves significant autocorrelation (ρ ¬ 0) against the null hypothesis of no autocorrelation (ρ = 0) at 0.01 level of significance. Box—Ljung statistic has empirically proven sound specifically in small samples when compared to Q-Statistic. This statistical significance reinforces the fact from Figure 2 and concludes that the deseasonalised NAV is non-stationary. There may be non-stationary in average deseasonalised NAV or variance or both.

sec.p: Table 7 exhibits the Unit root analysis. From Table 6, we understand statistically significant autocorrelation exists at various lags (–1 < ρ < 1), therefore, why not simply regress current quarter’s deseasonalised NAV on its lagged quarter’s deseasonalised NAV to determine the estimated ‘ρ’ is statistically equal to 1. If it is, then deseasonalised quarterly NAV is non-stationary. Thus, the null hypothesis is that the selected schemes contain Unit root against the alternative hypothesis that the selected schemes do not contain Unit root that is quarterly deseasonalised NAV is stationary (Random walk with drift that is model regressed with constant known as drift). The research reveals that we are unable to reject the null hypothesis of all schemes that is they have Unit root, except DWS Tax Saver fund and Escorts Tax plan at 10 per cent level of significance. Hence, we conclude that except aforesaid schemes others’ quarterly deseasonalised NAV are non-stationary.

sec.p: Table 8 exhibits the Unit root test (ADF) at first differences that is ΔDNAVt = DNAVt – DNAVt–1. The main problem associated with the non-stationary time series perhaps leads to spurious regression. Hence, transformation of non-stationary time series to stationary time series is required either through difference stationary or trend stationary methods. We applied difference stationary method to transform the non-stationary time series and to test the null the hypothesis that the first differences of deseasonalised NAV has Unit root at 0.01, 0.05 and 0.1 level of significance. The research reveals that all funds’ deseasonalised NAVs exhibit statistical significance in first differenced deseasonalised NAV at 0.01 and 0.05 level of significance. Hence, we conclude that the first differenced deseasonalised NAV is stationary that is, deseasonalised NAV does not contain Unit root.

caption.p: Unit Root Test—Augmented Dicky Fuller Statistic (First Differences)

sec.p: Table 9 exhibits the test for randomness of selected schemes, which facilitates us to understand whether quarterly NAV occurrence is pure random or follows any significant pattern. If it follows pure non-random pattern, it can be potentially exploited to predict the behaviour of NAV at future dates. In order to understand the randomness of NAV, the quarterly median NAV has been used as test case. At 10 per cent level of significance, we reject the null hypothesis of Baroda Pioneer ELSS’96, Birla Tax Plan, Canara Robeco tax saver fund and Principal tax saver fund and these funds behave randomly at 5 per cent level of significance. At 5 per cent level of significance, we reject the null hypothesis of BNP Paribas Tax advantage fund and conclude quarterly NAVs is non-random and we cannot reject the null hypothesis of this fund at 1 per cent level of significance. At 1 per cent level of significance, other all funds’ null hypothesis are rejected. This typically enlightens us that quarterly NAV of selected funds portray weak form of inefficient and perhaps quarterly NAV can be used to predict the future NAV.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: It is very apparent that the Equity Linked Savings Schemes (Tax Saver Schemes) are generally launched or they have seen enhanced fund size in the 3rd quarter or 4th quarter of a calendar year because majority of retail category investors plan their investment decisions only in the said quarters. It has been observed that the quarterly seasonal indices are statistically significant at 1 per cent level and we also witnessed appreciation in NAV during 3rd quarter as well as 4th quarter of a calendar year. The reason for appreciation in NAV on account of (a) Fund Managers would have exhibited superior stock selection skills and time the market to attract the prospective investors led to surge in market capitalisation (b) Scheme Units would have been bought at higher levels as investors pumped their resources for tax savings and (c) positive persistence of overall economic climate. Through graphical analysis as well as autocorrelation function (ACF), we found the deseasonalised NAV is non-stationary and it is statistically significant. ADF statistic strengthens the argument that deseasonalised NAV of all schemes contain Unit root at base level except DWS Tax Saver fund and Escorts Tax Plan that is deseasonalised NAV of schemes are non-stationary. In order to overcome from spurious regression, from one non-stationary time series on another non-stationary time series, we carried out ADF Unit root analysis on first differences (Difference stationary) and found the first differenced deseasonalised NAV of schemes are stationary at 0.01 and 0.05 level of significance. The economic theory portrays that if the time series data contains unit root, the level of recovery will be permanently below the trend in the long run. The test for weak form of market efficiency exhibited statistical significance at 0.01 and 0.05 level; hence, it is weak form inefficient that is the historical NAV facilitates to forecast the future NAV during the study period and a very cautious investor perhaps can gain advantage (abnormal returns) by using historical NAV.
